results.title: Time to learn
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Office of Intellectual Disability Services. Early Intervention Resource Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early Intervention Series”.
This program is for all professionals who come into contact with young children with multiple disabilities. The issues explored are: The Impact of the diagnosis at birth. The impact of delayed diagnosis. The importance of the relationship between the child, parent and professionals. How therapists work with families. * Difficult behaviours. Family Stress. Respite care.

results.title: Adrian
results.creator_credit: Allan Kidston and Victoria. Office of Intellectual Disability Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early Intervention Series”.
Adrian shows how children with developmental delay can be successfully integrated in kindergarten with cooperation between parents, kindergarten staff and the Early Intervention Program.

results.title: TVG-8610C Console
results.brief_description: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020
results.description: The Hanimex TVG-8610C is an early television games console circa 1978. This two-player console has detachable joysticks with 10 internally programmed games (similar to Pong) and allows the player to customise difficulty levels, automation, and keep score.
description_for_label: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020

details.label: Curatorial section

results.title: Early home consoles
results.brief_description: While the first home console, the Magnavox Odyssey, came out in 1972, it wasn’t the only launched in the decade. Around 1978, the two-player Hanimex TVG-8610C console was released for home use. Featuring detachable joysticks and 10 internally programmed games, it allowed players to customise difficulty levels, automation and keep score. Console like this needed to be run through the home TV to use as a monitor and also required a little domestic diplomacy with family members for a bigger share of screen time.

results.title: KOK 28mm hand cranked projector
results.brief_description: In 1912, the popular Pathé Kok camera and projector arrived, which used the more standard 28mm film and cast a 30-inch picture.
results.description:
28mm hand crank projector designed by Pathe. Designed for home use, the Pathe KOK projector uses non-flammable cellulose acetate safety film and an electric light. The projector is powered by a crank handle. Contains: projector, hand crank, metal cover, 2 x metal reels.
Sticker on reel says “The property of Visual Education Centre, Education Dept. Victoria”
See video of same model (modified) of projector in use: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SG9Nvly1UB4
Was ACMI Lending Collection/ACMI Collection in 2014 audit - NR says unclear, but should keep.
28 mm gauge metal projector on wooden base.Object functions.
description_for_label:

results.title: The Process of pollination
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
This film considers the function of pollination and the methods by which it is brought about. The characteristics of wind- and insect-pollinated flowers are illustrated and compared and the mechanisms for avoiding self-pollination are considered. Familiar garden examples are widely used and the resources of cine- macrography and time-lapse are fully exploited.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: How seeds are scattered
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Designed for primary schools, shows how plants produce flowers and then fruits which contain seeds. Different kinds of fruits and seeds - runner beans, laburnum tree, willow seeds, thistles, sycamore tree, are used to illustrate methods of dispersal by wind, water and animals.

results.title: How plants move
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Uses plants such as cress, beans, shamrocks and marrows to illustrate plant responses to light, gravity, water, day and night and touch. Time-lapse photography shows plant movements in detail. Gives a close-up examination of the trapping action of the venus fly-trap. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
